As we mark the two-year anniversary of #HurricaneHarvey, we see now things we didn’t see then. One of them is the toll it has taken on our hearts and our heads in addition to our homes and our lives.

Approaching the two-year anniversary of #HurricaneHarvey, I visited Meyerland residents this week to talk recovery. Like many of our #TX07 neighbors, they are still out of their homes. 

Harvey showed us how much we can do when we work together. We must & will continue to do so. pic.twitter.com/EL1TkIiblo

So glad to meet with @EqualityTexas and #TX07 constituents to talk about the critical LGBTQIA+ issues and the importance of the #EqualityAct, which I was proud to co-sponsor and will continue to work to enact. Thanks for coming to the district office! pic.twitter.com/N6QLk9L1ur

I look forward to continuing to work with our elected leaders in Houston, Austin, and Washington to make sure the next steps in this process are carried out efficiently and effectively.  https://fletcher.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=2176 … 6/6

I am proud that these bipartisan efforts culminated in the legislation that was incorporated into the supplemental appropriations bill requiring the publication of these rules.  When we work together to solve a problem, we get things done. 5/6

That’s why I have been working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to improve the recovery process and better prepare for future storms since the day I was sworn in to Congress.  Part of doing that is making sure that we deliver the funds we need for recovery. 4/6
We learned valuable lessons, including what we can accomplish when we come together as a community, as neighbors and as leaders.  And it is critical that we apply those lessons for the future. 3/6
Houstonians responded immediately with an outpouring of compassion, support, and creative solutions to the myriad problems our neighbors faced—whether canoes, clean clothes, or home-cooked food. 2/6
Two years ago, Hurricane Harvey deluged our Houston area in an unprecedented rain event, ultimately becoming one of the worst storms in United States’ history. 1/6

I join with Leader Hoyer and many of my colleagues, as well as advocates for Israel across the U.S., in calling for Prime Minister Netanyahu to reconsider and reverse this decision.

I have often disagreed with my colleagues’ statements about Israel, but I believe that education, engagement, and exchange of ideas is the best way to change views and resolve conflict. And working to resolve this conflict benefits us all.

PM Netanyahu’s decision to deny entry to Israel for members of Congress—Reps. Tlaib & Omar—not only violates its Ambassador’s promise not to deny entry to any member of Congress; it undermines the opportunity for them to gain an understanding of the complex issues in the region.

Visiting Israel provides an unparalleled opportunity to witness the challenges facing everyday Israelis and Palestinians, the complexities of the conflict, and the opportunities for progress. I benefited enormously from doing so just last week with a large bipartisan delegation.

That’s why I have co-sponsored the Protecting Patients from Surprise Medical Bills Act, which would implement a similar dispute resolution process for federally regulated plans.

As the editorial board points out Texas’ new law to end surprise billing is a good first step. Now it’s time for federal action so that the 40% of patients Texas’ law doesn’t cover are protected, too. https://www.houstonchronicle.com/opinion/editorials/article/Texans-off-the-hook-for-surprise-medical-14282165.php …

Public safety is the first obligation of government. I am committed to working with my colleagues in Congress to pass common-sense gun safety laws to keep all Americans safer. We have passed #HR8 and #HR1112. We will keep working. The Senate must, too.

I am grieving for El Paso, a vibrant community that does so much to take care of each other. I was there just yesterday, taken by the generosity and kindness of all that I met. El Pasoans are in my heart and on my mind as we learn more about this tragic shooting.

Our trip will allow us to visit with migrants and asylum-seekers, law enforcement officers at CPB and ICE, govt officials & diplomats in the U.S. & Mexico, & the many immigration advocates working in this area, as well as to see the facilities & conditions at the border 1st-hand.
I am glad to join my colleagues today in El Paso to visit the U.S.-Mexico border and get a better understanding of the issues we are facing and policy ideas to address them.
